'''Teresa Mattei''', also known as '''Teresita''' (1 February 1921 - 12 March 2013) was an Italian partisan and politician.
==Background== Born in [[Genoa]], Mattei in 1938, Mattei was expelled from all schools of the [[Regno d'Italia]] for openly criticizing in her classroom the [[Racial laws]].<ref name=bbb>{{cite news|last=Redazione Il Fatto Quotidiano|title=Addio a Teresa Mattei, era l’ultima donna rimasta tra le elette alla Costituente|url=http://www.ilfattoquotidiano.it/2013/03/12/addio-a-teresa-mattei-ragazza-di-montecitorio-ultima-vivente-tra-costituenti/528198/|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=Il Fatto|date=12 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Patrizia Gabrielli|title=Il 1946, le donne, la Repubblica|publisher=Donzelli Editore, 2009|isbn=886036440X}}</ref> Graduating in philosophy at the [[University of Florence]] in 1944,<ref>{{cite news|last=Lucía Magi|title=Teresa Mattei, símbolo de la resistencia al fascismo|url=http://internacional.elpais.com/internacional/2013/03/26/actualidad/1364331951_134814.html|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=[[El País]]|date=26 March 2013}}</ref> she was a partisan with the nom de guerre "Partigiana Chicchi".<ref name=bbb/><ref name=bio>{{cite book|last=Patrizia Pacini|title=La costituente: storia di Teresa Mattei|publisher=Altreconomia, 2011|isbn=8865160411}}</ref> She took part at the killing of philosopher and Fascist minister [[Giovanni Gentile]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Paolo Paoletti|title=Il delitto Gentile|publisher=Le Lettere, 2005|isbn=8871668944}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Antonio Carioti|title=«Sanguinetti venne a dirmi che Gentile doveva morire»|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2004/agosto/06/Sanguinetti_venne_dirmi_che_Gentile_co_9_040806079.shtml|accessdate=30 March 2013|newspaper=[[Corriere della Sera]]|date=6 August 2004}}</ref>
After the war, Mattei was a candidate for the [[Italian Communist Party|Communist Party]] to the [[Italian Constituent Assembly|Constituent Assembly]], in which she served as a secretary Bureau. Mattei was the youngest elected to the Constituent Assembly and was so called "the girl of [[Montecitorio]]".<ref name=bbb/><ref name=bio/>
She married [[Bruno Sanguinetti]]. Writer [[Gianfranco Sanguinetti]] is her son.
==Expulsion== In 1957 Mattei was expelled from the [[Italian Communist Party]] because of her opposition to [[Stalinism]] and to the [[palmiro Togliatti|Togliatti politics]].<ref name=bio/> She later became national director of the Italian Women Union (UDI) and introduced the use of [[mimosa]] for [[International Women's Day|the Women's Day]]<ref name=bbb/> at the request of [[Luigi Longo]].<ref name=florentine/> Mattei felt that the French symbols of IWD, [[Violet (plant)|violets]] and [[Lily of the Valley|lilies of the valley]], were too scarce and expensive to be used in poor, rural Italian areas, so she proposed the mimosa as an alternative.<ref name=bio/><ref>Laura Fantone, Ippolita Franciosi, ''(R)Esistenze: il passaggio della staffetta'', Morgana, 2005. ISBN 8889033312.</ref><ref name=florentine>{{cite news|first=Dierdre|last=Pirro|title=Teresa Mattei, Flower power |url=http://www.theflorentine.net/articles/article-view.asp?issuetocId=5425 |work=[[The Florentine]] |publisher= |date=2013-03-25 |accessdate=2013-04-01}}</ref>
She died in [[Lari, Tuscany]] at 92.<ref name=florentine/> She was the last living female member of the Constituent Assembly.<ref name=bbb/>
